Fixed. We didn't really test this path because our classpath container is 
typically computed by PDE and added as part of the 'Update Classpath' 
operation. But we have to support this way as well.

We also fixed the scenario in which our container is added during the creation 
of the new project. We can successfully create the entry, but when we try to 
expand it, a null pointer exception is fired in the tab. This is probably 
because we didn't bind the container with the entry so it cannot be resolved. 
There is nothing we can do about it. Our container only makes sense if added to 
the java project that is a plug-in or fragment (has plugin.xml/fragment.xml in 
the root). Since this is a new Java project without these files, we don't have 
a model object in our model for this file and cannot map it.

Suggest to be prepared for unresolved containers and expect 'null' from 
JavaCore.getClasspathContainer.

Wouldn't it be better to have a container that returns a empty array of 
IClasspathEntries? Getting 'null' for JavaCore.getClasspathContainer is ugly 
for me, as I don't even get a description for the entry then that I could 
present.

I think a container should be returned, but it resolves to an empty array of 
IClasspathEntries and its configuration page says, container only usable for 
plugin projects.
